title: 108_hr3242
content:
The "Specialty Crops Competitiveness Act of 2004" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The findings and purpose of the Act are outlined in section 2. Congress finds that a secure domestic food supply is a national security imperative, a competitive specialty crop industry is necessary for producing nutritious fruits and vegetables, increased consumption of specialty crops benefits health and economy, and improvements in Federal agriculture policy are needed to promote consumption and increase competitiveness. The purpose of this Act is to make changes in Federal agriculture policy to increase fruit, vegetable, and nut consumption and improve the competitiveness of United States specialty crop producers in the face of global market challenges. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "specialty crop" includes fruits, vegetables, tree nuts, dried fruits, and nursery crops. The term "State" refers to States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. The term "State department of agriculture" is the agency responsible for agriculture within a State. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide grants to States for fiscal years 2005-2009 to enhance specialty crop competitiveness based on production value ratios. Minimum grant amounts will be subject to appropriations. Each State shall receive a minimum grant amount of $100,000 annually under this section, regardless of the calculated amount. To be eligible, a State department of agriculture must submit an application meeting specified requirements to the Secretary of Agriculture. Grant funds are intended to supplement State expenditures. The State plan must enhance the competitiveness of specialty crops and identify the lead agency. The Secretary of Agriculture reviews applications to ensure compliance with the grant program's purpose. Noncompliance may result in disqualification for one or more years. The State plan must enhance specialty crop competitiveness and identify the lead agency. Noncompliance with grant program purpose may lead to disqualification from future grants. States receiving grants must conduct audits of fund expenditures and submit them to the Secretary of Agriculture within 30 days. $44,500,000 is authorized for grants under this section for fiscal years 2005-2009. TITLE II--SPECIALTY CROP ADVANCEMENT

SEC. 201. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR SPECIALTY CROPS.

Authorized $2,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2005-2009 for technical assistance in agriculture.

SEC. 202. REDUCTION IN BACKLOG OF AGRICULTURAL EXPORT PETITIONS. The Secretary of Agriculture aims to reduce the backlog of export permit applications for US agricultural commodities without compromising resources managing sanitary and phytosanitary issues. An annual report on progress must be submitted to relevant committees. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit an annual report detailing the total number of applications processed, backlog applications processed, percentage of backlog applications completed, and the number of backlog applications remaining. SEC. 203. REPORT ON SANITARY AND PHYTOSANITARY EXPORT ISSUES. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit a report on significant sanitary and phytosanitary issues affecting specialty crop exports within 180 days of this Act's enactment. TITLE III--SPECIALTY CROP RESEARCH SEC. 301. METHYL BROMIDE ALTERNATIVES. TITLE III--SPECIALTY CROP RESEARCH

SEC. 301. The Secretary of Agriculture will prioritize methyl bromide alternative research, reevaluate the phase-out deadline, and assess costs for growers. $5,000,000 is authorized annually for fiscal years 2005-2009.

SEC. 302. NATIONAL SPECIALTY CROP RESEARCH PROGRAM. SEC. 302. NATIONAL SPECIALTY CROP RESEARCH PROGRAM. Research grants for improving specialty crop production in the US. SEC. 303. SPECIALTY CROP COMMITTEE. Establishment of a Specialty Crop Committee under the National Agricultural Research, Extension, and Teaching Policy Act of 1977. The Specialty Crops Competitiveness Act of 2004 established a permanent specialty crops committee to study research programs for the industry. Non-Advisory Board members can be appointed to the committee, serving at the executive committee's discretion. The committee must submit an annual report to the Advisory Board on its findings. The Specialty Crops Competitiveness Act of 2004 established a permanent specialty crops committee to study research programs for the industry. The committee must submit an annual report to the Advisory Board containing recommendations to improve specialty crop production efficiency, competitiveness in research programs, quality of fresh fruits and vegetables, crop protection tools, prevention of invasive pests, and development of new specialty crop products and uses. The Specialty Crops Competitiveness Act of 2004 established a permanent committee to study research programs for the industry. The committee's recommendations aim to improve specialty crop production efficiency, competitiveness in research programs, food safety, mechanization, and irrigation techniques. The Secretary of Agriculture considers these recommendations in the annual budget recommendations. The Secretary must report on how they addressed recommendations from the specialty crops committee as required by section 1105 of title 31, United States Code. TITLE IV--PEST AND DISEASE RESPONSE FUND

SEC. 401. PEST AND DISEASE RESPONSE FUND. Establishment of the Pest and Disease Response Fund on the Treasury books for reimbursement of services provided by the Secretary of Agriculture. Amounts in the Fund remain available until expended. The Secretary has discretion to use Fund amounts for emergency eradication and research activities in response to agricultural pests and diseases. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2005-2009. From 2005 to 2009, $1,000,000 is authorized for the Secretary of Agriculture to deposit in the Pest and Disease Response Fund. SEC. 402. IMPORT AND EXPORT REGULATION REVIEW. The Secretary of Agriculture will conduct a peer review with the National Plant Board on import and export requests under the Plant Protection Act. The review will focus on risk assessments and data quality, with results to be submitted to the Secretary and Congress within 180 days. SEC. 403. MAINTENANCE OF FREDERICKSBURG INSPECTION TRAINING CENTER. $1,500,000 authorized annually for maintenance of Agricultural Marketing Service inspection training center in Fredericksburg, Virginia for fiscal years 2005-2009.
